content.text: Comments can be used to explain Kotlin code, and to make it more readable. It can also be used to prevent execution when testing alternative code.
content.html: Comments can be used to explain Kotlin code, and to make it more readable. It can also be used to prevent execution when testing alternative code.

content.text: Single-line comments starts with two forward slashes ( // ).
content.html: Single-line comments starts with two forward slashes (//).

content.text: Any text between // and the end of the line is ignored by Kotlin (will not be executed).
content.html: Any text between // and the end of the line is ignored by Kotlin (will not be executed).

content.text: This example uses a single-line comment before a line of code:
content.html: This example uses a single-line comment before a line of code:

content.code_html:
// This is a comment
println("Hello World")

content.text: This example uses a single-line comment at the end of a line of code:
content.html: This example uses a single-line comment at the end of a line of code:

content.code_html: println("Hello World")  // This is a comment

content.text: Multi-line comments start with /* and ends with */ .
content.html: Multi-line comments start with /* and ends with */.

content.text: Any text between /* and */ will be ignored by Kotlin.
content.html: Any text between /* and */ will be ignored by Kotlin.

content.text: This example uses a multi-line comment (a comment block) to explain the code:
content.html: This example uses a multi-line comment (a comment block) to explain the code:

content.code_html:
/* The code below will print the words Hello World
to the screen, and it is amazing */
println("Hello World")
